From a series of 40 miniatures (c. 1270-80) depicting Old and New Testament subjects, originally designed for a psalter. They form a kind of compendium of Bible stories and may have served a didactic function since children were taught Latin by learning and construing passages from the Psalms. The curiously monumental treatment of the figures may indicate the influence of wall- or panel-painting. The serpent has not only a female face but also a woman's headdress and hairstyle. As is conventional, the depiction of four apples apparently represents the sequence of actions by which the serpent tempts Eve to take the apple and then to tempt Adam.
